question: Question_07_(b)
statement:
The length of time in minutes it takes students to solve a certain
mathematics problem (on probability) is a continuous random variable
whose probability density function is

\[f(x) = \begin{cases} k\cos(x/10)\sin^2(x/10), & \text{if } 0 \leq x \leq 5\pi, \\
0, & \text{otherwise.} \end{cases}\]

(b) What is the probability that a student will take less than $5\pi/2$
minutes to complete the problem?
sols:
A student takes at most 5$\pi$/2 minutes to complete the question if his
completion time is anywhere between 0 and 5$\pi$/2. Hence the probability we
are looking for is

\begin{align*}
\text{Prob}(a \leq X \leq b) &= \int_a^b f(x)\,dx \\
&= \int_0^{5\pi/2} \frac3{10} \cos\left(\frac{x}{10}\right)\sin^2\left(\frac{x}{10}\right)\,dx \\
&= \int_0^{1/\sqrt{2}} 3u^2\,du \\
&= \left.u^3\right|_0^{1/\sqrt{2}} \\
&= \frac1{2\sqrt{2}}.
\end{align*}

We used the substitution \emph{u} = \emph{sin}(\emph{x}/10), \emph{du} =
1/10 \emph{cos}(\emph{x}/10), so that \emph{u}(0) = 0 and \emph{u}(5$\pi$/2)
= \emph{sin}($\pi$/4) = $\scriptstyle 1/\sqrt{2}$ from
\href{http://wiki.ubc.ca/Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH101/April_2005/Question_7_(a)}{part
(a)}.
hints:
For a continuous random variable \emph{X} with probability density
function \emph{f(x)} the probability that an event \emph{a} ≤ \emph{X} ≤
\emph{b} happens is

\[\text{Prob}(a \leq X \leq b) = \int_a^b f(x)\,dx.\]
